official_title: Phase III Trial of Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS) Versus Hippocampal-Avoidant Whole Brain Radiotherapy (HA-WBRT) for Brain Metastases From Small Cell Lung Cancer
brief_title: Testing if High Dose Radiation Only to the Sites of Brain Cancer Compared to Whole Brain Radiation That Avoids the Hippocampus is Better at Preventing Loss of Memory and Thinking Ability
cancer_type_display: A study for patients with small cell lung cancer that has spread to the brain.
cancer_tags: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Stage IV Lung Cancer AJCC v8
prior_treatments_excluded: Prior radiotherapy to the brain, including SRS, WBRT, or prophylactic cranial irradiation (PCI)
Planned infusion of cytotoxic chemotherapy on the same day as SRS or HA-WBRT treatment
Current use of other N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonists (amantadine, ketamine, or dextromethorphan)

key_inclusion_summary: Pathologically proven diagnosis of small cell lung cancer.
Must have brain metastases no larger than 4 cm in diameter, and the total tumor volume must be 30 cm or less.
Karnofsky performance status of 70 or greater.
Patient must be proficient in English or French Canadian to complete neurocognitive testing.
key_exclusion_summary: Prior radiotherapy to the brain (SRS, WBRT, or PCI).
Planned infusion of cytotoxic chemotherapy on the same day as brain radiation.
Current use of certain NMDA antagonists like amantadine, ketamine, or dextromethorphan.
